I have been playing this game for over a year as a Killer Main player and I have seen the developers  consistently hamstring, makes things harder and remove any kind of benefit or desire to play as a Killer Main player.

For example, for my Killer Main character my Field of View (FOV) is about 40 degrees!!  Here is a screenshot from today

https://imgur.com/a/vjGK2Y1

I can see an area two feet wide and two feet high and this causes headaches and eye-aches after like 15 minutes of playing, Motion sicknesss if you keep on going to point of just giving up because you can keep up with the survivors nor can you hit them because of broken FOV and you CAN'T change it at all (Only game I have EVER played like this!)

All of the benefits and concesssion seem to be made to Survivors player and I would not suggest you purchase this game under any circumstance.  Developers are constantly "Re-balancing" (Changing) things constantly and making perks and any other add-ons of features of this game a joke and little more than comestic.

I have lost all interest and desire to play this and F*k you Behavior and Starbreeze for this broken ass game!

DBD is BHVRâ€™s first (and only remaining) full game release. Historically, they made ports for well-known titles and finally took a punt by paying a few million for the rights to produce DBD. Now theyâ€™ve got a staff of around 700, most of which likely work on DBD, and theyâ€™re utterly incapable of putting out a single update that doesnâ€™t break a bunch of mechanics or introduce a litany of bugs. In DBDâ€™s genesis, I was forgiving of BHVRâ€™s slapdash releases and slipshod attempts at balancing the meta, but the gameâ€™s been out for five years now. In that time, BHVR has made literally millions from DBD (I saw one article last year that indicated theyâ€™d made around $434m), and yet they canâ€™t be bothered to address the gameâ€™s health whatsoever. It took them years to figure out that there were way too many pallets on maps, which, if you played just [i]five[/i] matches as Killer, was blindingly obvious; how do you not see this as a developer? Killers like Freddy took almost two years to receive complete reworks to make them competitively viable, and the forums screamed the entire time about how bad he was. I'm not saying take the diehard community's word for it, but there's no smoke without fire. How do you not see this? When a new update comes out then you can expect a whole slew of insane bugs to come with it... EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. I donâ€™t expect perfect first time, but we're multiple years from release and the company has obviously grown in thanks to DBD's success and yet they STILL cannot put out even a mostly bugfree update. It's just embarrassing now. [i]How do you not see this?[/i]

Another recent example: colourblindness options took a combination of four years of player requests, a dedicated redditor posting weekly memes about it for a [i]YEAR[/i], and an industry professional publicly calling BHVR out before they [i]finally[/i] added colourblindness settings that most other games have on release. Even worse, they had the absolute cheek to claim that theyâ€™d been â€œworking on it for monthsâ€ when theyâ€™d previously dismissed demands for it as a complete non-priority. This is utterly disgusting.

More issues: one update broke the outlines on generators that made it nearly impossible for some players to see and, instead of instantly reverting the update, it was in there for months. What else? Completely unnecessarily they announced a HUD change, which almost no one asked for and wasnâ€™t needed. It, admittedly, had two good new features, but came at the apparent cost of splitting the previously combined elements to instead be all over the screen. So you had to look in multiple areas to understand the game state. When these flaws were pointed out then BHVR (quite petulantly) claimed this had taken â€œmonths of workâ€ and they couldnâ€™t [b][i]possibly[/i][/b] consider walking it back or making changes. Are you serious? It was literally just moving the locations of some features. Iâ€™m no developer but Iâ€™m confident you can just move back the location of HUD elements in â€“ and Iâ€™ll be generous here â€“ two weeks, but probably [i]considerably[/i] less than that. Oh, and, btw, they did eventually cave to pressure (despite saying they wouldnâ€™t) and found a compromise that was basically enough like the original they couldâ€™ve just left everything as it was in the first place.

Oh and some people have hacked the in-game reporting system (which BHVR basically admits does nothing) to show a list of really disgusting and racist language at any player that tried to report those players for hacking. Iâ€™m pretty sure this oneâ€™s been in the game for months now and BHVR just shrug their shoulders.

Iâ€™ve often felt that DBD started as a fun little joke of a game and then it got big. Really big. I think its success took BHVR by surprise. The initial flimsy game architecture that they threw together to get the design off the ground in 2016 collapses at the mere whisper of a new DLC, patch, or basically any change whatsoever. The game critically needs an infrastructural overhaul to improve stability and tackle optimisation and bugs, which are rife and continue to show up in droves with each new patch. For instance, the Nemesis DLC came with a new map that was taken out of rotation a day after release as it had stability issues. BHVR all but admits that their quality control and playtesting is non-existent as they chase a relentless release schedule for more money.

BHVR is the kid in the class that acts out constantly, and weâ€™re the teachers and parents that continue to allow it because we donâ€™t want to give up the loveable aspects of the game we enjoy. And thatâ€™s the heart of the issue: DBD has no competition. BHVR can do whatever they like because thereâ€™s nowhere else to go in retaliation. Competition would force BHVR to shape up, but most similar games donâ€™t have the funding or fail to execute the mechanics to make them worth playing. Thus BHVR continues to sit tyrannically on its throne treating the playerbase however it damn well pleases.

Sigh.

[h1]The Actual Game[/h1]

Developers aside, at this point in its life, DBD is actually a very solid game. Balance is at the best point itâ€™s been, build options are wider than ever, in-game quests give you reasons to keep playing, and the gameplay itself â€“ while still stale â€“ has been refined enough that you get a fun game out of nearly every match. 

You should know that DBD is NOT a thriller/horror game, itâ€™s an action game with a horror theme, which means itâ€™s rarely scary, and, more often than not, the action is slapstick and silly. When the Killerâ€™s on your tail then get ready to run around a car three times because thatâ€™s the way the action plays out. Itâ€™s silly, but itâ€™s very telling of the kind of action game DBD is. Youâ€™ll feel the fantasy of hunting or being hunted for your first hours with the game, but itâ€™ll soon wear off when you realise Survivors have a relatively relaxed gameplay experience. Meanwhile, Killers are under constant stress to perform or face of a ton of hate mail and in-game taunting from the Survivors.

Furthermore, the gameâ€™s baseline design is entirely propped up by perk-based bonuses players select pre-game to alter match mechanics in some way. Generators completing too fast? Take Ruin. Killer focusing you? Take Decisive Strike. Killer camping hooks to secure kills? Borrowed Time. Some of these things, at this point, should just be baseline game elements. But then lower skill players would probably lose out and enjoy games less, so BHVR stands by and does nothing because theyâ€™re scared to hurt their profits instead of actually make the game better.

However, despite all I've said about BHVRâ€™s appalling management, the crazy thing about Dead by Daylight is... I keep playing? The game idea itself is still thrilling and, over time, it's finally reached a state thatâ€™s bizarrely addictive to play. It's also stressful, frustrating and HORRIFICALLY toxic in places, but I play on anyway... On that note, the toxicity's been there since day one and BHVR still hasn't implemented anything close to an effective reporting system. How? It's clearly an issue and you've had years to think on it. Get your act together, BHVR.

In short, I'm saying don't get DBD because the developers are a total clown fiesta, but it can also be fantastic fun often enough (particularly with friends) if you don't mind putting up with some of the most ridiculously appalling game design execution ever.

No. Stay the hell away.

This game is awfully balanced. The base concept is so compelling, it draws people to it to this day, but it is awfully executed. There just aren't enough things for the survivors to do, so the game ends up being very one-dimensional and thus, impossible to balance. 

The devs straight up told the community they cannot make this a balanced, competitive game and they just want to make it fun. It's fun if you are a survive with friends survivor, otherwise, it's a pain. Survivors are in 100% control of the game and if they don't make mistakes, the only killer that can get them is Nurse. Every other killer can be looped and chased around the map for death and there is nothing you can do about it.

There is a youtuber called Marth 88 who tested this. In his tests, with coordination and meta perks 98/100 killers DID NOT PIP UP AGAINST THEM.

THIS MEANS THAT THE WINRATE OF KILLERS AGAINST A SKILLED, COORDINATED TEAM WITH META PERKS IS 2% !!! TWO FUKCING PERCENT! And this is an evidenced, proper, scientific study, not an opinion piece, you cannot challenge it without a similar sample size of your own.

Yet, the devs refuse to address this. The rationale is simple: there are 4x as many people playing survivor as killer. So they will continue to balance the game to make it entertaining for survivors. Nothing else matters. 

Stomping a group of randoms is fun, but a coordinate team will make your life hell and there is NOTHING you can do about it.

Avoid like the plague.

Okay, first off: Take every review with a grain of salt. A lot of people are angry because of reworks and the Developers are getting hate because people can't solve their own problems. People don't want nerfs that hurt them or buffs that help the enemy and get angry and frustrated that the developers are actually TRYING (Not always succeeding) to help balance the game and make it a fun experience for all.

That being said, the game is quite fun. Gameplay is a system of cat and mouse chasing, where you must repair the generators and escape without being caught and killed. This vanilla experience is altered as you will gain perks and items to use against the survivors or killer which alter gameplay. Overall, the game is quite interesting based on the unique take of the multiplayer horror genre. 

Make a game where you aren't getting scares from things jumping out, but the everlasting dread that creeps into your heart when you are finishing a gen and slowly hear a heartbeat.... Walking towards you.... It knows where you are... and it will get you... or they will walk past you, kick the gen, and keep going as your friends across the map just blew up a generator three times in a row like idiots. The game is not traditional horror, as you aren't scared by the killer, you aren't scared by getting caught. The scare comes from progression towards the exit and somebody alerting the killer and leading the killer to you.

Killers have a harder time then you would think however. In a one versus one match, Killer just needs to find the survivor and hook them once. However, with four survivors, all of them being able to do generators, means that the killer has to be cunning and use their ability to mess with the survivors, keep them off generators, and keep them away from the exits. These are more often the masochistic players, as they are basically gluttons for punishment from the community. 

The DLCs are great, and hold amazing perks behind them. With some, you get amazing perks, such as BBQ and Chili from Leatherface which increases Bloodpoint payout, the currency of the game, then you have some like Myers whom are higher levels of play killers that have abilities that are amazing. The only exception is the Nightmare on Elm Street DLC and the Cosmetic DLCs. When Freddy was introduced, he was viewed as OP, so he got nerfed to Hell, but is currently facing a possible rework. Then the Cosmetics don't do anything. If you do want to spend money on this game for cosmetics: go with Charity Case, it is for charity, so good cause, am I right?

Now, you are going to hear the community is toxic. Yeah, that is basically it, as a lot of players will be total jerks and will leave you behind or will have bad manners and teabag. However, that is only around 20-40% of players, and honestly, everyone else is pretty open and cool. 20-15 is the learning period for new players now, and is where you will make most of your friends or meet the cool and friendly survivors, even if some of them are quite angry (I apologize in advance if you see me in game, I usually get angry because I just get tunneled so hard around half the time, and the other half, people teabag)

This game is a great game overall, and is just limited by the Development team and how the player base is overall shattered and confused.

 If you are looking to buy this game, wait until there is a sale, pick it up for around ten dollars, and see about getting your friends to join you. If you really love the game and enjoy it, buy DLC packs and help teach the next generation of players. 

If you hate it, just refund it and write a review detailing what was bad and what was good, that will help give out a pro/con for the game. I praised it, but I didn't give it much flak. This is because I think that the game gets too much crap from people who are angry at the developers, or people who play the game and don't like specific things. 

My recommendation: Watch some videos of gameplay for both Killer and Survivor. If you like what you see, try it out. If you don't like it, refund it, then write a review with pros and cons. If you do, write a review to help people understand all of the issues or be willing to teach people how to play the game.
